{{Infobox Government agency |agency_name = Russian Hydrographic Service |nativename = Гидрографическая служба России |nativename_a = |nativename_r = |logo = Russia, Flag of hydrogrphic vessels of the Navy 2000.svg |logo_width = 200px |logo_caption = Flag of hydrographic vessels of the Russian Navy (since 2001) |seal = |seal_width = |seal_caption = |formed = November 1777 |preceding1 = |preceding2 = |dissolved = |superseding = |jurisdiction = [[Russian Federation]] |headquarters = [[St. Petersburg]] |employees = |budget = |minister1_name = |minister1_pfo = |minister2_name = |minister2_pfo = |chief1_name = [[Sea captain|Capt.]] Sergey V. Travin |chief1_position = Head of Navigation and Oceanography of the Ministry of Defence{{cite web |url = http://structure.mil.ru/structure/forces/hydrographic/leader.htm |title = Травин Сергей Викторович |work = Структура |publisher = [[Ministry of Defence (Russia)|Ministry of Defence]] |accessdate = 22 August 2016 }} |chief2_name = |chief2_position = |parent_agency =[[Ministry of Defence (Russia)|Ministry of Defence]]
[[Russian Navy]] |child1_agency = Russian Lighthouse Administration |child2_agency = |website = |footnotes = }} The '''Russian Hydrographic Service''', full current official name '''Department of Navigation and Oceanography of the Ministry of Defence of the Russian Federation''' ({{lang-rus|Управление навигации и океанографии Министерства обороны Российской Федерации}}),[http://rusnavy.com/industry/index.htm?ELEMENT_ID=4888 Department of Navigation and Oceanography of the Ministry of Defence of the Russian Federation - Russian Navy] is [[Russia]]'s [[hydrographic office]], with responsibility to facilitate navigation, performing [[hydrographic survey]]s and publishing [[nautical chart]]s. Since the Russian state is of such a vast size and nature that it includes many different seas, long and indented coastlines and a great number of islands, as well as a complex system of waterways and lakes, [[surveying]] has been an indispensable activity for the Russian Navy since its modernization at the time of Czar [[Peter the Great]] in the 17th century. The hydrographic service has been historically attached to the [[Russian Navy]] and the agents and supervisors of hydrographic works have been largely [[naval officer]]s throughout its history. Russia is a member of the [[International Hydrographic Organization]]. ==Competences and functions== [[File:Маяк Осиновец.JPG|thumb|The [[Osinovetsky Light|Osinovetsky Lighthouse]] near the [[Neva]] entrance is one of the tallest lighthouses in the world.]] Despite having undergone a number of name changes along its history, the main functions of the Hydrographic Service of the Russian Navy have been quite consistently the following: *Providing specific services to the Navy, including other branches of the [[Russian Armed Forces]], related to the Russian maritime and coastal areas, as well as navigable inland waters. These services are of a strategic order and encompass the following fields: **[[Navigation]] and [[hydrography]]. **[[Hydrometeorology]] **[[Surveying|Surveys]] *Navigation and hydrographic support of maritime activities within Russian waters and implementation of the international [[Safety of Life at Sea]] Convention regulations in the waters under Russian jurisdiction.{{cite web |url = http://structure.mil.ru/structure/forces/hydrographic/about.htm |title = Гидрографическая служба ВМФ |work = Структура |publisher = [[Министерство обороны Российской Федерации]] |accessdate = 20 August 2016 }} Navy Hydrographic Service - Structure - Russian Ministry of Defence ==History== [[File:Admiraltejstvo 1716.jpg|thumb|170px|Russian Admiralty (1716)]] ===Background=== {{see also|Admiralty Board (Russian Empire)}} At the time of [[Peter the Great|Peter I]] hydrographic surveys were carried out following personal [[decree]]s of the emperor through the [[General admiral]]. Hydrographic tasks were always performed by Naval officers, who from 1724 onward began to work under instructions from the [[Admiralty Board (Russian Empire)|Admiralty Board]]. By 1746 important matters concerning hydrography were entrusted to Fleet Captain [[Alexey Nagayev]] who compiled the first [[atlas]] of the [[Bering Sea]], as well as of the [[Baltic Sea]] in 1752. Nagayev's charts were very detailed for its time and, despite a few shortcomings, his atlas of the Baltic Sea was republished in 1757, 1788, 1789 and 1795, serving Russian mariners for more than 50 years. ===Foundation and first phase (1777-1885)=== [[File:Russia Naval 1829 hydro.svg|thumb|170px|Flag of the Hydrographer General (1828)]] [[File:Aleksandr Sergeevich Menshikov 2.jpg|thumb|170px|[[Alexander Sergeyevich Menshikov|Alexander Menshikov]]]] In 1777 the Admiralty Board founded the Russian Hydrographic Service, implementing a plan that marked the beginning of systematic drawing of nautical charts.С этой чертежной началось централизованное производство морских карт в России, а дата утверждения штата чертежной — 2 (13) ноября 1777 г. — является датой основания ныне существующего Центрального картографического производства Военно-Морского Флота. In 1799 a committee for the dissemination of marine sciences and the improvement of the drawing of charts was created, and in 1807 the Russian Lighthouse Administration was established so that the lighthouse system in Russian shores, shoals and islands would follow an organized pattern and be provided with regular, state-controlled maintenance. The first director of this section was [[Leontiy Spafaryev]].[http://www.farosferrol.com/Bibliografia/bibliografia8.pdf Igor Alexeev, ''Lighthouses of the Baltic Sea''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080820061330/http://www.farosferrol.com/Bibliografia/bibliografia8.pdf |date=2008-08-20 }} In 1827 the special Office of the Hydrographer General was established. In the same year the Corps of Naval Navigators was founded, the chief of which was also a hydrographer. The first and only general of the newly-instituted body was hydrographer Admiral [[Gavril Sarychev|Gavril Andreevich Sarychev]] (in office 1827-31), after whose death the management of the office was transferred to the [[Chief of Naval Staff (Russia)|Chief of Naval Staff]] Prince [[Alexander Sergeyevich Menshikov|A. S. Menshikov]]. The first and only director of the hydrographic depot was F. F. Schubert (in office 1827-37).[http://www.imha.ru/1144531015-russkaya-gidrografiya-do-1917-goda.html#.V7LdKvl97IU Russian Hydrography before 1917] In 1837 the former institutions dealing with hydrography were abolished and all the management of the hydrographic section was transferred to the newly-instituted Russian Hydrographic Department, the directors of which were: *[[Alexander G. Villamov|A. G. Villamov]] (1837–54) *Baron [[Ferdinand von Wrangel|F. v. Wrangel]] (1854–55) *[[Michael Reinecke|M. v. Reinecke]] (1855–59) *[[Semyon Ilyich Zelenoy|S. I. Zelenoy]] (1859–74) *[[Grigory Vevel von Krieger|G. A. Vevel von Krieger]] (1874–81) *[[Theodosius Fedorovich Veselago|T. F. Veselago]] (1881) *[[Pavel Nikolaevich Nazimov|P. N. Nazimov]] (1892-1898). ====Publications==== The Hydrographic Office engaged in the periodical publication of notes, devoted both to hydrographic information, as well as information on other sectors of naval affairs. The committee, established in 1799, published: *In 1801 - ''"[[Notice to Mariners]]"'' (1 vol.) *From 1807 to 1827 - ''"Notes of the State Admiralty Department"'' (13 pieces) *From 1835 to 1837 - ''"Notes of the Hydrographic Depot"'' (5 parts) *From 1842 to 1852 - ''"Notes of the Hydrographic Department."'' *1854-83 - ''Annual reports of the Director of the Hydrographic Department.'' ===The Main Hydrographic Office (1885-1917)=== [[File:Russia Naval 1912 hydro.svg|170px|thumb|Flag of the Main Hydrographic Office (1885)]] [[File:Nekmangrund.jpg|170px|thumb|[[Lightvessel|Lightship]] ''[[Nekmangrund]]'' (1898) off [[Hiiumaa]].[http://diving.ee/articles/art103.html Lightship "Nekmangrund"]]] [[File:Vice-admiral Gilterbrandt.jpg|130px|thumb|[[Yakov Gilterbrandt]] (1842-1915)]] In 1885 the Russian Hydrographic Department was overhauled and renamed as 'Main Hydrographic Office' —Главное гидрографическое управление (ГГУ)— of the Admiralty. Its chief was the former director in charge of the [[lighthouses]] and navigation of the Baltic Sea, [[Vice Admiral]] [[Roman Ivanovich Bazhenov|R. Bazhenov]], who was also the chairman of the Maritime Scientific Committee —Морского учёного комитета. 1886 saw the establishment of the meteorological department. In 1891 the fields of drawing, engraving, lithography and printing were integrated into the maritime cartography section and from 1897 this section began successful experiments printing nautical charts using aluminum printing plates. In 1902 a new building with a photographic department, including a workshop introducing innovative photographic reproduction techniques, was built within the premises of the Main Hydrographic Office. By 1904 the new techniques had been mastered by the staff and high-quality material began to be printed.[http://www.imha.ru/knowledge_base/base-16/1144531015-russkaya-gidrografiya-do-1917-goda.html ''150 лет гидрографической службе военно-морского флота.'' Исторический очерк. 1977 г.] The duties of the Hydrographic Department at the time included: *Planning and carrying out surveys. *Preparation of [[map]]s, [[atlas]]es, [[sailing directions]] and other guidance materials for safe navigation, as well as making periodical corrections —when needed. *Erection and proper maintenance of [[lighthouse]]s, [[electric beacon]]s, [[Air-sea rescue|rescue stations]], [[navigational beacon|towers]], [[day beacon]]s, [[buoy]]s, signals, and other warning devices to improve navigation safety. *Supply of military tools such as maps, [[piloting (navigation)|pilot manuals]], signals manuals and other guides. *Inspection and evaluation of ships' [[logbook]]s in order to gather relevant navigational, astronomical, magnetic, and other observations. The jurisdiction of the Main Hydrographic Office included the management of: *[[Pilotage instructions]] and [[navigational instrument]]s workshops in St. Petersburg and [[Mykolaiv|Nikolaev]] *The Russian Maritime Observatory in [[Kronstadt]] and Nikolaev. *The [[weather station]]s on the shores of the Russian seas. *The [[Semaphore line|maritime semaphore telegraph]] in Kronstadt. *The [[signal station]]s in [[Mykolaiv|Nikolaev]], [[Bogdanovka]], [[Parutino]], [[Adzhigol]] and [[Ochakov]]. The period between 1885 and 1917 was characterized by full-scale construction and modernization of lighthouse equipment, [[compass]] technology and improvements in the printing of nautical charts. The 1910-1915 [[Arctic Ocean Hydrographic Expedition]], led by [[Rear Admiral]] [[Boris Vilkitsky|Boris A. Vilkitsky]] on [[icebreaker]]s [[Vaygach (icebreaker)|Vaigach]] and [[Taymyr (icebreaker)|Taimyr]] mapped the last blank areas of the northern coast of Eastern [[Siberia]] —which were the last unmapped coastal areas of [[Eurasia]], and gathered as well a vast amount of oceanographic and meteorological data.[http://epic.awi.de/Publications/Polarforsch1975_1_6.pdf The Arctic Ocean Hydrographic Expedition 1910-1915] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101016154350/http://epic.awi.de/Publications/Polarforsch1975_1_6.pdf |date=2010-10-16 }} The heads of the Main Hydrographic Office were: *[[Konstantin Ivanovich Mikhailov|Konstantin Mikhailov]] (1898-1903) *[[Yakov Gilterbrandt]] (1903-1907) *[[Andrey Vilkitsky]] (1907-1913) *[[Mikhail Yefimovich Zhdanko|M. Y. Zhdanko]] (1913-1917) ===The Soviet period (1917-1992)=== [[File:USSR, Flag auxiliary fleet 1924 survey military.svg|170px|thumb|Flag of the [[commanding officer]] on hydrographic and [[maritime pilot|pilot]] vessels (1924-1935)]] [[File:USSR, Flag auxiliary fleet 1924 survey civil.svg|170px|thumb|Flag on hydrographic vessels not commanded by naval officers (1924-1935)]] [[File:USSR, Broad Pendant 1924 survey.svg|300px|thumb|Pennant flown on Ubek vessels (1924-1935)]] [[File:USSR, Broad Pendant 1935 beacon.svg|300px|thumb|Pennant of the Commander of a hydrographic unit (1935-)]] [[File:USSR, Flag auxiliary fleet 1935 beacon.svg|170px|thumb|[[Stern flag]] on hydrographic, [[maritime pilot|pilot]] vessels and [[Lightvessel|lightship]]s (1935-)]] [[File:USSR, Flag auxiliary fleet 1950 beacon.svg|170px|thumb|Flag on hydrographic and lightships (1950-1964); and hydrographic ships (1964-1992)]] [[File:Alexander varnek.jpg|140px|thumb|[[Alexander Varnek (hydrographer)|Alexander Varnek]] (1858-1930).]] After the initial period of instability that followed the 1917 [[Russian Revolution]] against the Imperial Government, the Hydrographic Office slowly returned to its duties as the situation calmed down and the Soviet takeover was completed. The work and dedication of hydrographers such as [[Konstantin Neupokoev]], ensured that the service returned to normality.''Синюков, В. В.'' Александр Васильевич Колчак : Учёный и патриот : в 2 ч. / В. В. Синюков; отв. ред. А. П. Лисицын ; Ин-т истории естествознания и техники им. С. И. Вавилова РАН. — М.: Наука, 2009. — {{ISBN|978-5-02-035761-7}} (ч. 2), С. 34 Czarist names and symbols were quickly removed, the former hydrographic institution being renamed as the 'Main Hydrographic Office of the Russian Republic' —Главное гидрографическое управление Российской Республики. Between 1918 and 1922 hydrometeorological service units named '''Ubek''' (Убек) were established for the management of navigation safety measures. The Ubek regulated the particular hydrographic zone —in [[Arkhangelsk]] for example it was 'Ubek-North'— as part of the unified local authority directly responsible to the central Soviet government. In 1924 the Hydrographic Office was renamed the 'Central Hydrographic Department of the [[USSR]]' and a set of new flags and pennants was issued. Barely two years later, in September 1926, the office underwent another name change; the new name was "Hydrographic Department of the Office of Naval Forces of the Workers' and Peasants' [[Red Army]]" (UVMS Hydrographic Department of the Red Army) —Гидрографический отдел Управления Военно-морских сил Рабоче-крестьянской Красной Армии. In 1927 the name was simplified to 'Hydrographic Office UVMS Red Army' —Гидрографическое управление УВМС РККА. [[Emperor Nicholas II Land]] first partially charted by Boris Vilkitsky in 1913, but still not fully surveyed when it was renamed ''Severnaya Zemlya'' by the [[Presidium]] of the [[Central Executive Committee of the Soviet Union|Central Executive Committee of the USSR]] in 1926,{{cite web |url=http://newslab.ru/news/222324 |title=Депутаты Законодательного собрания Красноярского края против переименования островов архипелага "Северная Земля" |language=Russian |date=27 May 2007 |website=newslab.ru |accessdate=12 August 2015}} was the last blank area on the vast map of the Soviet Union. Vilkitsky's expedition, which in 1913 sighted and surveyed a section of the eastern coastline of what he assumed was a single landmass, had to concentrate on the Siberian continental shore in order to prepare the way for the [[Northeast Passage]] and he had no means to make a comprehensive survey further north.Alfred S. McLaren, ''Unknown Waters: A First-Hand Account of the Historic Under-ice Survey of the Siberian Continental Shelf by USS Queenfish (SSN-651), University of Alabama Press 2008, {{ISBN|978-0817316020}}, p. 130 Finally a hydrographic expedition of the Arctic Institute of the USSR led by [[Georgy Ushakov]] and [[Nikolay Urvantsev]] thoroughly surveyed the large Severnaya Zemlya archipelago in 1930–32, making it the last sizable territory on [[Earth]] to be put on the map. {{cite journal|author= Barr, William |year= 1975|title= Severnaya Zemlya: the last major discovery |journal= Geographical Journal|volume= 141|pages= 59–71|issue= 1|doi= 10.2307/1796946}} In 1935 the Ubek were replaced by hydrographic offices subordinate to the commander of the fleets and [[flotilla]]s. In 1937 the 'Hydrographic Office UVMS Red Army' was renamed the "Hydrographic Office of the Workers' and Peasants' Navy" —Гидрографическое управление Рабоче-крестьянского Военно-морского флота (РК ВМФ). The design of the flags and pennants used by the office also underwent changes. In 1940 the Hydrographic Office was renamed 'Hydrographic Office of the Navy' —Гидрографическое управление ВМФ. The following year, owing to the dire situation of the [[Great Patriotic War]] (1941-1945), a [[Task Force]] in the Hydrographic Department of the Navy was formed in [[Moscow]] by the [[Chief of the General Staff (Russia)|Chief of the General Staff]] in order to deal more effectively with the emergency matters caused by the war in Russian soil and waters. In postwar times, after the initial period of reconstruction was over, the Soviet Navy began the challenging task of creating an oceanic fleet carrying [[nuclear weapon]]s. The 1960-1970 decade saw the introduction and development of [[ballistic missile submarine]]s as part of the strategical aims of the Soviet fleet. These submarines were designed to be able to navigate in all areas of the oceans, including in the [[Arctic Ocean]] under the [[Arctic ice pack|ice cover]].{{cite book | last = Gardiner | first = Robert | author2 = Chumbley, Stephen | authorlink = | title = Conway's All the World's Fighting Ships 1947-1995 | publisher = Conway Maritime Press | year = 1995 | location = London | pages = | url = | doi = | isbn = 1-55750-132-7 }} In the field of navigation, during this period [[radar]] reflectors, [[radio beacons]] and other modernized signal systems were introduced. The technological leap of that decade would impose a radical change in the navigational, hydrographic and hydrometeorological support of the Navy. During this period the need for innovative and detailed survey and mapping of the Earth's [[geophysics]], including [[gravity field|gravity]] and [[magnetic field]]s, became of the utmost importance for the Hydrographic Service of the Soviet Union. At that time, using its survey vessels, the department spearheaded a comprehensive study of large areas of the [[Atlantic]], [[Pacific Ocean|Pacific]], [[Indian Ocean|Indian]], [[Arctic Ocean|Arctic]], as well as of the then little explored [[Southern Ocean]] off the coast of [[Antarctica]]. As a result, a huge volume of data on [[bottom topography]], [[physical field]]s, and hydrophysical characteristics of the water masses, among other pioneering [[oceanographic]] information of the oceans, were collected. In 1972, owing to [[Cold War]] dictated priorities, the Hydrographic Office of the Navy was overhauled and transformed into the 'General Directorate of Navigation and Oceanography of the Ministry of Defense of the USSR' —Главное управление навигации и океанографии Министерства обороны СССР (ГУНиО МО). The 1970-1980 decade was marked by an increased international prominence of the 'General Directorate of Navigation and Oceanography of the Ministry of Defense'. Since then the Hydrographic Service of the USSR officially represented the interests of the Soviet Union —in the same manner that the organization that replaced it in later years would do for the Russian Federation— in the [[International Hydrographic Organization]] and the [[International Association of Lighthouse Authorities]], as well as the interests of the Ministry of Defence in the [[Intergovernmental Oceanographic Commission]] of [[UNESCO]]. The heads of the Hydrographic Service of the USSR''История Гидрографической службы Российского флота.'' Т.4. — Спб.: Издание ГУНиО МО РФ, 1997 were: *[[Eugene Byalokoz]] (1917-1919) *[[Pavel Messer]] (1920-1922) *[[Sergei Blinov]] (1922-1925), 1st term *[[Mikhail Viktorov]] (1925-1926) *Sergei Blinov (1926-1928), 2nd term *[[Izrail Razgon]] (1928-1932) *[[Vasily Vasilyev (Flag officer)|Vasily Vasilyev]] (1932-1937) *[[Nikolai Gorbunov (Flag officer)|Nikolai Gorbunov]] (1937-1939) *[[Iakov Lagushkin]] (1939-1947) *[[Mikhail Kulikov]] (1947-1948) *[[Vladimir Tributs]] (1949-1952) *[[Pavel Sergeyevich Abankin|Pavel Abankin]] (1952-1958) *[[Valentin Chekurov]] (1958-1963) *[[Anatoliy Ivanovich Rassokho|Anatoliy Rassokho]] (1963-1985) *[[Arkady Mikhailovsky]] (1985-1988) *[[Yuri Zheglov]] (1988-1994) ===The Russian Federation (from 1992 onward)=== [[File:Russia, Flag of hydrogrphic vessels of the Navy 1992.svg|170px|thumb|Flag of hydrographic ships and lightships (1992-2001)]] [[File:Комарицын АА.jpg|170px|thumb|Adm [[Anatoly Komaritsyn]].]] In the wake of the [[dissolution of the Soviet Union]] the 'General Directorate of Navigation and Oceanography of Defense of the USSR' would be placed under the [[Russian Federation]], the legal successor of the USSR. In 1992 the service was renamed as the 'Main Directorate of Navigation and Oceanography of the Ministry of Defense of the Russian Federation' —Главное управление навигации и океанографии Министерства Обороны Российской Федерации (ГУНиО Минобороны России). Depending from their location, some of the vessels of the Soviet Hydrographic Service managed to be released and join the navies of the newly-formed republics after the breakup of the USSR. These ships were usually renamed and overhauled or transformed before being put into use, for example the GS-13 small hydrographic vessel that had been launched in 1986 in [[Soviet Lithuania]] became the [[Pereyaslav (U512)]] when it was made part of the [[Ukrainian Navy]] in November 1995. Although the basic designs were left unchanged, prominent Communist-era symbols —such as the [[hammer and sickle]] and the [[red star]], were removed from the flags of the Russian Hydrographic Service and the blue and white [[Russian Navy Ensign]] was restored. In 2001 a new regulation introduced slight alterations in the symbols that had been adopted in 1992 following the fall of the USSR. In 2006 the name of the Russian Hydrographic Service would be changed to 'Department of Navigation and Oceanography of the Ministry of Defence of the Russian Federation' —Управление навигации и океанографии Министерства Обороны Российской Федерации (УНиО Минобороны России), its current official name. Russian military presence in Arctic waters resumed in the summer of 2013 when Hydrographic Service vessels belonging to the [[Northern Fleet]] sailed to [[Rudolf Island]] in [[Franz Josef Land]]. The area had been neglected by the armed forces for a long time in the years that followed the fall of the USSR.[https://www.rt.com/news/russian-arctic-navy-restitution-863/ RT - Russian military resumes permanent Arctic presence (14 September 2013)] The heads of the Hydrographic Service of the Russian Federation in recent times have been: *Yuri Zheglov (1988-1994) *[[Anatoly Komaritsyn]] (1994-2006) *[[Sergey Viktorovich Kozlov|Sergey Kozlov]] (2006-2010) *[[Alexander Shemetov]] (2010-2013) *[[Sergey Travin]] (2013-) ==Vessels== The vessels operating for the Russian Hydrographic Service have been historically of two orders or categories. To the first category belong those vessels that were built specifically as survey ships, of which there are different classes, and to the second, other kind of vessels of the Russian Navy that, although not especially built for the purpose, have eventually engaged in survey operations. The latter usually undertook surveys for specific periods of time during their naval service, such as the a four-masted tall ship [[Kruzenshtern (ship)|Kruzenshtern]], which performed hydrographic surveys between 1961 and 1965.[http://www.vitiaz.ru/congress/en/thesis/64.html L. Sergeeva (Baltic Fishing Fleet State Academy, Kaliningrad, Russia): Academic and research activities on board STS «Krusenstern»] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080926103028/http://www.vitiaz.ru/congress/en/thesis/64.html |date=2008-09-26 }} ===Types of vessels=== ====Hydrographic vessels==== {{div col|colwidth=22em}} *[[1896 Project]], large hydrographic boats *[[Baklan class|Baklan]] (19920 Project), large hydrographic boats *[[Yaroslavets]] (G376 Project), middle-sized hydrographic boats *[[Flamingo (vessel type)|Flamingo]] (T-1415 Project), middle-sized hydrographic boats *[[382 Project]], small hydrographic boats *[[727 Project]], small hydrographic boats *[[Kaira (vessel type)|Kaira]] (1403 Project), small hydrographic boats *[[Drofa]] (16830 Project), small hydrographic boats {{div col end}} ====Oceanographic vessels==== *[[97b Project]], [[Vladimir Kavrayskiy (ship)|Vladimir Kavrayskiy]] only ship built *[[852 Project]], 6 vessels built, including [[Admiral Vladimirskiy (ship)|Admiral Vladimirskiy]] *[[22010 Project]] ====Survey vessels==== {{div col|colwidth=18em}} *[[Ocean class]], large survey vessels *[[Kamchadal (vessel type)|Kamchadal]] *[[Nord class]] *[[860 Project]] *[[Arktika class]] (861 Project) *[[862 Project]] (Yug class), 9 ships built; includes hydrographic survey ship ''Senezh''.[http://www.korabli.eu/galleries/oboi/voennye-korabli/senezh Гидрографическое судно «Сенеж» проекта 862 Северного флота РФ] *[[865 Project]] *[[870 Project]], small survey vessels *[[871 Project]], small survey vessels *[[872 Project]], small survey vessels *[[16611 Project]], small survey vessels *[[Alex Maryshev class]], small survey vessels *[[V19910 Project]], small survey vessels {{div col end}} ====Images of selected vessels==== {| |- valign="top" |[[File:ГиСу Иней.jpg|thumb|320px|Hydrographic survey ship Iney (1909) in the [[Gulf of Ob]].]] |[[File:Гидрографическое судно Челекен.jpg|thumb|300px|[[Arktika class]] hydrographic survey ship Cheleken (1970)]] |[[File:«Адмирал Владимирский».jpg|thumb|320px|Survey ship Admiral Vladimirsky (1975) of the Hydrographic Service of the Soviet Union]] |} {| |- valign="top" |[[File:«Сенеж» в Североморске.jpg|thumb|330px|[[Northern Fleet]] hydrographic survey ship Senezh (1979) in [[Severomorsk]].]] |[[File:«БГК-2090».jpg|thumb|320px|[[Baklan class]] hydrographic survey ship BGK-2090 in [[Astrakhan]].]] |[[File:RIAN archive 987729 Viktor Faleyev hydrographic survey vessel floated out.jpg|thumb|320px|Viktor Faleyev hydrographic survey vessel. Launching ceremony (2011) in [[Vladivostok|Maly Uliss Bay]]]] |} ==See also== * [[Admiralty Board (Russian Empire)]] * [[Arctic Ocean Hydrographic Expedition]] * [[Arctic and Antarctic Research Institute]] * [[List of lighthouses in Russia]] * [[List of Russian admirals]] * [[Lightvessel#Russian lightvessels|Russian lightvessels]] * [[Northern Sea Route]] * [[Spy ship]] * [[Stone of Tmutarakan]], allegedly one of the first hydrographic documents in Russia. ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== *{{commonscat inline}} *[https://www.jstor.org/stable/208561 The Siberian Sea Road: The Work of the Russian Hydrographical Expedition to the Arctic 1910-1915] *[http://www.hydro-international.com/content/article/hydrographic-society-russia-64 Hydrographic Society Russia - Hydro International] *[http://www.iho.int/mtg_docs/rhc/HCA/HCA12/HCA12-07.4Aq_National_Report_Russian_Federation.pdf Department of Navigation and Oceanography. Of the Russian Federation. Ministry of Defence] *[http://redstarwhitestar.blogspot.com/2015_06_01_archive.html Military History of the Cold War - Spy Ships] *[https://ria.ru/science/20150928/1287170975.html Hydrographic vessel "Senezh" completed the Arctic expedition (ru)] {{Armed Forces of the Russian Federation}} [[Category:Government agencies of Russia]] [[Category:Scientific organizations based in Russia]] [[Category:Russian Navy]] [[Category:National hydrographic offices]] [[Category:Lighthouse organizations]] [[Category:1777 establishments in the Russian Empire]] [[Category:Surveying organizations]] [[Category:Soviet Navy]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} {{Use British English|date=July 2013}} [[File:Circle Line Hijack.jpg|thumb|A reveler urges silence on one of the Space Hijacker's [[Circle line party|Circle line parties]] on the [[London Underground]] on 14 March 2003. The tactic for keeping the party unnoticed by the authorities was to keep quiet while the train was in the stations. The first Space Hijackers Circle Line Party took place on 10 March 1999.]] The '''Space Hijackers''' is a group originating in the [[United Kingdom]] that defines itself as "an international band of [[anarchism|anarchitects]] who battle to save our streets, towns and cities from the evils of [[urban planner]]s, [[architect]]s, [[Multinational corporation|multinationals]] and other hoodlums". ''[[Time Out (magazine)|Time Out]]'' magazine has described the group as "an inventive and subversive group of London ‘Anarchitects’ who specialise in reclaiming public spaces – usually without permission."<ref name="timeout">{{cite web |url=http://www.timeout.com/london/features/1975/12.html |title=London's secret scenes |accessdate=2007-10-11 |pages=12 |work=Features |publisher=Time Out}}</ref>
The group's activities have included "guerrilla benching"<ref>Sawyer, Patrick. "Guerilla gardeners stage a sit-down protest", ''[[Evening Standard]]'', 2007-04-04. Accessed 2008-01-10.</ref> — restoring benches that had been recently removed and bolting them to the ground — organising a midnight game of [[cricket (sport)|cricket]] in the centre of the [[City of London]] financial district, and satirising the glossy architects' drawings that are displayed on the perimeter of luxury apartments by depicting children’s playgrounds and other projects they believe to be actually desirable.<ref name="timeout"/> Many of these activities aim to bring to people's attention the role which corporations play in society in a different light.<ref name="newstatesman">{{cite web |url=http://www.newstatesman.com/200206170013 |title=How to beat the adman at his own game |accessdate=2007-10-11 |last=Hari |first=Johann |authorlink=Johann Hari |date=2002-06-22 |work=World Affairs |publisher=''[[New Statesman]]''}}</ref>
==Purpose== {{quote | text =Space Hijacking is mental graffiti, designed to change how the space is perceived and take some of the power away from the people who own or design the space. | sign =Space Hijacker Agent Bristly Pioneer<ref name="mute">{{cite journal |last=Albert |first=Saul |date=March 2002 |title=Graffitiing the Brainspace |journal=[[Mute Magazine]] }}</ref> }}
The Space Hijackers exist mainly to change the public's perception of spaces it regularly uses, mainly by staging unexpected events. Their explicit objective is "to effect and change the physical space of architecture", and, eschewing violent protest and other forms of transparent [[direct action]], their methods aim "to invade and re-brand corporate space".<ref name="anarchitexts">{{cite book | last = Richardson | first = Joanne | title = Anarchitexts | publisher = Autonomedia | location = Brooklyn | year = 2004 | isbn = 978-1-57027-142-7 }}</ref> They believe that the use of physical space is becoming more and more politicised, and thus in order to break apart from that politicisation, they stage events that are typically 'unusual' for that particular space, 'hijacking' it and hoping to change people's perception of the use of that space forever. They believe that increasing politicisation usually leads to increased subordination and discrimination and other forms of domination and control and so Space Hijackers claim to seek to break down and deconstruct society's notions of space. They seek to effect this by attempting to undermine the authority of the owner's "[[hermeneutics|text]]", confusing and re-contextualising it and thereby making apparent the possibility of an alternative future.<ref name="anarchitexts"/> Protests tend to be non-violent and Space Hijacker projects usually involved a good sense of fun.<ref name="bizarre"/> Protest strategy includes involving passers-by.
The Space Hijackers have many contacts with other groups, and involve themselves with all sorts, including but not limited to [[Critical Mass (cycling)|Critical Mass]], [[Independent Media Center|Indymedia]], [[Rhythms of Resistance]] samba band, free media collective [http://www.iconscious.co.uk/ iconscious], [[Reverend Billy and the Church of Stop Shopping]] and [[LHC|evoLhypergrapHyCx]]. The Hijackers pulled several of these groups together in Anarchitecture Week 2005, a week of anti-building related activities in response to, and hosted at the same time as Architecture Week.
==Projects==
Formed in 1999, their first major action was the [[Circle Line Party]] - a party on [[London Underground]]'s [[Circle line (London Underground)|Circle Line]] which attracted around 150 people armed with [[Sound reinforcement system|sound system]]s, disco lights and bars all disguised as luggage.<ref name="bizarre">{{cite journal |last=Aitch |first=Iain |date=August 2001 |title=Mind The Reality Gap |journal=[[Bizarre (magazine)|Bizarre]] |issue=49 }}</ref> {{Quote box | quote =''We're a bunch of fuck-wits, really. So if we can do this, then you can.'' | source =–Agent Robin, quoted in ''[[Red Pepper (magazine)|Red Pepper]]'', May 2004 edition.<ref>"[http://www.redpepper.org.uk/article203.html# Creative occupation ]", ''[[Red Pepper (magazine)|Red Pepper]]'', May 2004. Retrieved 2008-01-10</ref> | width =20% | align =right }}
{{Quote box | quote =''If you don't look like your average protester, there's less of a barrier to break down.'' | source =–Agent Bristly Pioneer, quoted in ''[[The Observer]]'', Jan 2008 edition.<ref>"[http://observer.guardian.co.uk/review/story/0,,2243558,00.html ]", ''[[The Observer]]'', Jan 2008 .</ref> | width =20% | align =right }}
Projects of the Space Hijackers have included the following:
* Becoming the [http://www.protestlondon2012.com/ Official Protestors of the London 2012 Olympics] * [[Zapatista Army of National Liberation]] protests<ref name="adbusters">{{cite journal |date=October 2001 |title=Mental Environment Index |journal=[[Adbusters]] |issue=38 }}</ref> * Spoof Planning Permission Applications<ref>''[[Computer Arts Projects]]'' Issue 99. Accessed 2008-01-10.</ref> * A Second and Third [[Circle Line Party]] * Inner-City Midnight Cricket<ref name="timeout"/> * [http://www.iconscious.co.uk/oldsite/film/mayday05/ Mayday Anarchists vs Members of Parliament Cricket] * "arms dealing" at the [[DSEI]] arms fair * Using a [http://www.iconscious.co.uk/oldsite/film/mayday05/challenge.htm parking meter space as a rented office] * 'Supporting' Nike with banners including "Sweatshops ROCK!" at their sponsored events * 'Auctioning' a tank outside the [[DSEi]] weapons exhibition in 2007 <ref>http://www.spacehijackers.co.uk/html/projects/dsei07/index.html</ref> * Running a 'professional protest stall' on the London Police march for more pay, with advice for the police on their rights as protesters
===G-20 London Summit=== During the 2009 [[2009 G-20 London summit|G-20]] demonstrations in London, members of the Space Hijackers protest group<ref name=indymedia>{{cite web |url=http://london.indymedia.org.uk/articles/956 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-04-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090404030236/http://london.indymedia.org.uk/articles/956 |archivedate=4 April 2009 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref name=GuardianBlog/><ref name=BBCNewsProtest>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/7975597.stm BBC News: "G20 call for action amid protests"]</ref> drove their [[Alvis Saracen]] armoured personnel carrier (known to them as "the tank") into the [[City of London]]<ref name=BBCNewsVideo /> and parked it outside the [[Royal Bank of Scotland]] in Bishopsgate.<ref name=BBCNewsVideo>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/7976444.stm BBC News video of Saracen outside RBS] (no commentary) (1 April 2009)</ref> The Saracen, which had been painted bright blue with black and white chequer stripes in a mock police livery, was equipped with CCTV.<ref name=indymedia/> Eleven Hijackers were arrested<ref name=GuardianBlog>{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/news/blog/2009/mar/31/g20-summit-protests | work=The Guardian | location=London | title=G20 summit and protests: live blog | first=Matthew | last=Weaver | date=2009-04-01 | accessdate=2010-05-23}}</ref><ref name=BBCNewsProtest /> and charged on two counts of impersonating police officers. On 27 January 2010, the Crown Prosecution Service dropped all charges against the Space Hijackers because there was "not enough evidence to provide a realistic prospect of conviction".<ref>https://www.standard.co.uk/news/g20-bra-girl-charged-for-posing-as-a-police-officer-6790841.html</ref> The Space Hijackers won compensation from the police, but their names and biometric data were kept on file for 18 months, allegedly because of a dispute between the Metropolitan Police and the City of London Police.<ref>http://www.hja.net/press-releases/city-london-police-pay-g20-protesters-take-18-months-remove-personal-data-national-database/</ref>
== Citations == {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.spacehijackers.org Space Hijackers] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20041129182713/http://sweatlondon.com/ Sweat London] (archived copy), used for the pro-Nike campaign * [http://www.anarchitectureweek.co.uk Anarchitecture Week] * [http://www.protestlondon2012.com Space Hijackers Official protest site for the London 2012 Olympics]
[[Category:Anarchist organisations in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Cultural appropriation]] [[Category:Culture jamming]] [[Category:Psychogeographers]]

revision.text:
A '''Special Protection Area''' ('''SPA''') is a designation under the [[European Union]] [[Birds Directive|Directive on the Conservation of Wild Birds]]. Under the Directive, Member States of the [[European Union]] (EU) have a duty to safeguard the [[habitat (ecology)|habitats]] of [[Bird migration|migratory birds]] and certain particularly threatened birds. Together with [[Special Area of Conservation|Special Areas of Conservation]] (SACs), the SPAs form a network of protected sites across the EU, called [[Natura 2000]]. Each SPA has an EU code – for example the North Norfolk Coast SPA has the code ''UK9009031''.<ref name=EUBirdDir>{{cite web | title = The Birds Directive | work = Environment | publisher = [[European Union]] | url = http://ec.europa.eu/environment/nature/legislation/birdsdirective/index_en.htm}}</ref>
==In the United Kingdom== As at 21 September 2006, there were 252 classified SPAs and 12 proposed SPAs in England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland.
The Conservation (Natural Habitats etc.) Regulations 1994 implement the terms of the Directive in Scotland, England and Wales. In [[Great Britain]], SPAs (and SACs) designated on land or in the [[intertidal]] area are normally also notified as [[Site of Special Scientific Interest|Sites of Special Scientific Interest]] (SSSIs), and in [[Northern Ireland]] as Areas of Special Scientific Interest (ASSIs). For example, the [[Broadland SPA]] in eastern England is a conglomeration of some 28 SSSIs. SPAs may extend below [[Tide|low tide]] into the sea, and for these areas SSSI notification is not possible. In Scotland, some SPAs have been classified without any underpinning designation by SSSI.{{Clarify|date=February 2010}}<!-- Are these terrestrial or marine? -->
==In Poland== {{Further|Special Protection Areas in Poland}} ''Special Protection Areas'' for [[Bird migration|bird]]s in [[Poland]] are called OSOPs ({{lang-pl|Obszar Specjalnej Ochrony Ptaków}}). As of 2005, there were 72 OSOP Areas designated as such.
==In Portugal== The [[Castro Verde SPA]] extends into six municipalities of [[Baixo Alentejo Subregion]]: [[Aljustrel Municipality]], [[Almodôvar Municipality]], [[Beja Municipality]], [[Castro Verde Municipality]], [[Mértola Municipality]] and [[Ourique Municipality]], a total area of 79,007 hectares (790 km <sup>2</sup>).
==In Spain== The Spanish term is ''ZEPA''. There were 644 Spanish sites as at 2016.<ref> {{cite web | title = "Zonas de especial protección para las aves de España" | work = Environment | publisher = [[Ministry of Agriculture, Food and Environment (Spain)]] | url = http://www.magrama.gob.es/es/biodiversidad/temas/espacios-protegidos/red-natura-2000/zepa.aspx }} </ref>
== In the Czech Republic == The Czech Republic use the term ''Ptačí oblast'' (PO, bird area) for SPAs. There were declared 41 bird areas by the government directives between 2004 and 2009.<ref>[http://www.mzp.cz/cz/narizeni_vlady Ptačí oblasti – nařízení vlády]</ref> They cover 9% of the state area.
== See also == *[[Area of Special Protection]] (UK designation unrelated to Special Protection Area) *[[Convention on the Conservation of European Wildlife and Natural Habitats]] *[[List of conservation topics]] *[[List of Special Protection Areas in the United Kingdom]] *[[Protected areas of the United Kingdom]] *[[Ramsar Convention]] *[[Specially Protected Areas of Mediterranean Importance]] *[[UK sites recognised for their biodiversity conservation importance]]
==References== <!-- Integrate global and inline references --> <!-- Handles automatically numbered inline references --> {{Reflist}}
<!-- General references. Please adjust 'li value' to follow on from last inline reference number. For full details, see Template:Reflist#Continuing_the_references For details of standardised citation templates, see Wikipedia:Citation templates --> {{refbegin}}
#<li value="1"> #
{{refend}}
==External links== {{commons category|Special Protection Areas}} *[http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:31979L0409:EN:HTML Council Directive 79/409/EEC of 2 April 1979]

page.title: Vehicle registration plates of American Samoa

revision.comment: Possibly the last time I tidy up this article: Mexico also standardized the size of its license plates at 6" x 12" in 1956
revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=November 2017}} The [[Territories of the United States|U.S. unincorporated territory]] of [[American Samoa]] first required its residents to register their [[motor vehicle]]s and display [[Vehicle registration plate|license plate]]s in 1924. In 1956, the United States, Canada and Mexico came to an agreement with the [[American Association of Motor Vehicle Administrators]], the [[Automobile Manufacturers Association]] and the [[National Safety Council]] that standardized the size for license plates for vehicles (except those for [[motorcycle]]s) at {{convert|6|in|cm}} in height by {{convert|12|in|cm}} in width, with standardized mounting holes.{{cite magazine |last=Garrish |first=Christopher |date=October 2016 |title=Reconsidering the Standard Plate Size |magazine=Plates |publisher=[[Automobile License Plate Collectors Association]] |volume=62 |number=5}} American Samoa adopted these standards in 1977. ==Baseplates== ===1945 to 1969=== {|class="wikitable" |- !Image !Date issued !Design !Slogan !Serial format approximately 200 | |- |[[File:Blank License Plate Shape.svg|150px]] |1964 |white on green |''none'' |123 |1 to approximately 380 | |- |[[File:Blank License Plate Shape.svg|150px]] |1965 |white on red
